header.title: VOODOOS AND OBEAHS: Phases of West India Witchcraft
header.category: Western Esotericism, Occultism, Comparative Religion, Anthropology

central_thesis: The book aims to provide a scholarly, differentiated account of Voodoo and Obeah, distinguishing them from each other and other forms of magic. It traces Voodoo's origin to African Ophiolatry (serpent worship) from Whydah and Obeah's origin to Ashanti witchcraft (poisoning and malevolent magic), detailing their development, syncretic modifications, and practical mechanics in the West Indies, particularly Haiti and Jamaica, in contrast to sensationalized public perceptions.

structure_content.summary: This chapter critiques the sensationalized depictions of Voodoo and Obeah in popular media and previous works, like Seabrook's 'Magic Island'. The author establishes his intent to provide an accurate, scholarly, and historically contextualized analysis based on extensive research and personal observation, differentiating between fact and fiction in West Indian magical practices.

This chapter delves into the origins of serpent worship (ophiolatry) in Africa. It discusses different theories on its genesis and focuses on Python worship as indigenous to Negro culture, with main foci in Uganda and West Africa. The author distinguishes between serpent 'cult' (beliefs and acts less defined) and formal 'worship' (involving superhuman beings, priesthood, sacrifice, and ritual), emphasizing the non-poisonous python as the object of reverence.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter II. SERPENT CULT AT WHYDAH
structure_content.summary: This chapter provides a detailed historical account of the serpent cult at Whydah (Slave Coast, West Africa), considered the prototype of Haitian Voodoo. It describes the organized priesthood, sacred python (often non-poisonous), rituals of consultation and sacrifice, and the belief in the serpent as a medium to the Supreme Being. It also traces the cult's origin to the late seventeenth century, noting its eventual decline and modifications.

This chapter examines the transplantation and evolution of the Whydah serpent cult into Haitian Voodoo. It details the roles of the Voodoo King and Queen, the serpent as an intermediary, secret nocturnal assemblies, and the syncretism with Catholic and other African beliefs. It also differentiates Voodoo from the later, more violent Don Pédro cult, which involved pig and sometimes human sacrifice, highlighting the ongoing controversy surrounding cannibalism.

This chapter traces the etymology of 'Obeah' to the Ashanti word 'Obayifo' (witch/wizard), distinguishing it from the Ashanti religious system (Myalism). Obeah is defined as antisocial magic, often involving poisoning, while Myalism is depicted as white magic for community welfare. The chapter describes the tools and methods of Obeah practitioners, emphasizing their cunning, knowledge of poisonous herbs, and the fear they inspired.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter V. DEVELOPMENT OF OBEAH IN JAMAICA
structure_content.summary: This chapter details the development of Myalism and Obeah in Jamaica. Myalism, rooted in Ashanti religious practices, initially combatted Obeah but later underwent modifications, becoming a force in slave uprisings. Obeah in Jamaica is characterized by its secrecy, use of charms, poisons, and its association with malevolent spirits and devil worship. The chapter highlights the confusion between Myalism and Obeah and the legal attempts to suppress them.

This chapter summarizes the author's findings, reaffirming the distinct origins and natures of Voodoo (Whydah Ophiolatry) and Obeah (Ashanti witchcraft). It reiterates their syncretic evolution and modifications in the West Indies due to slave conditions and contact with other cultures. The author concludes that while pure forms of these practices may have declined, their underlying spirits and influences persist, often merging with other spiritual movements like Revivalism.

key_concepts.definition: Serpent worship, specifically the veneration of the non-poisonous python, identified as the proto-form of Voodoo originating in West Africa (Whydah).

A religious system derived from African Ophiolatry, transplanted to Haiti. It involves the worship of a serpent deity (Damballa) as an intermediary to a Supreme Being, with organized priesthood (Papaloi, Mamaloi), rituals, and ecstatic dances. Later became syncretic with Catholic and other African beliefs.

A form of witchcraft or antisocial magic originating from Ashanti practices in Africa, later transplanted to the West Indies (Jamaica). It involves the use of charms, poisons, incantations, and malevolent spirits (Sasabonsam) to cause harm, sickness, or death. It is distinct from organized religion and often performed secretly for personal gain or revenge.

An Ashanti tribal religion practiced in Jamaica, originally focused on community welfare and combating Obeah. It involves dances, spirit possession, and rituals to 'dig up Obeah' (exorcise malevolent influences). Later became syncretic with Christian revivalism, leading to confusion with Obeah practices.

A variant or offshoot of Voodoo that emerged in Haiti, characterized by more violent rituals, quicker tempo dances, and the pig as the sacrificial animal, sometimes involving human sacrifice. It is distinct from Voodoo's original focus on the serpent.
An Ashanti forest monster or evil spirit, associated with witches (Obayifo) and black magic. In the context of Obeah, its aid is solicited for malevolent purposes.
The Ashanti word for witch or wizard, associated with black magic, vampirism (sucking blood/juices), and often using poisons. It is the direct African antecedent to the concept and practice of Obeah.
A magical charm or amulet prepared by a Voodoo or Obeah practitioner, believed to confer protection or cause harm. Ingredients often include herbs, animal parts, dirt, and personal items.

The high priest and priestess of Voodoo in Haiti, claiming inspiration from the serpent god and having authority over the community. They lead ceremonies, prescribe obligations, and receive offerings.
The serpent god in Haitian Voodoo, incarnating the spirit Dagbe, an adder (non-poisonous serpent) is its symbol and worshipped as an intermediary to the Supreme Being.

practical_system.description: The text describes two primary, distinct systems: Voodoo and Obeah. Voodoo, originating from African Ophiolatry, is a structured religion with a priesthood, rituals, and veneration of a serpent deity (Damballa) as an intermediary to a Supreme Being. Obeah, stemming from Ashanti witchcraft, is a practice of antisocial magic, often involving the use of poisons and charms for personal gain or harm, lacking a formal religious structure but relying on fear and knowledge of herbs/toxic substances. Myalism, an Ashanti religious practice in Jamaica, initially countered Obeah but later merged with Christian revivalism.
tools: Voodoo: Non-poisonous serpent (adder/python), drums (Bamboula, for tempo and passion), calabashes with small stones/corn grains (shakers), Banza (Bass viol), altars, boxes for serpents, red handkerchiefs (for King/Queen), blue girdles.

Obeah: Charms (Obi) made of rags, feathers, bones (cats, dogs, lizards), animal skulls, grave dirt, broken bottles, poisonous herbs/plants (e.g., branched calalue/solanum), pounded glass, arsenic, snuff-boxes, phials with liquids/powders, rope (hangman's cord), sticks (e.g., from 'wizard's tree'), string, iron objects (snake-like amulet), 'cabalistic books' with diagrams/scrawls.

Myalism: White robes, wands, green bush/twigs, white cloths, drums, eggs, fowls, water (in a basin to catch shadows), specific herbs/infusions (e.g., branched calalue) for inducing trance or restoring consciousness.
rituals: Voodoo: Secret nocturnal assemblies, adoration of the adder/serpent (in a box through bars), faithful protestations, renewal of secrecy oaths, ecstatic convulsive dances, oracle consultations through possessed priestesses, tribute offerings, sometimes incorporating Catholic rituals (vestments, processionals).
Don Pédro: More hurried dances, pig sacrifice (sometimes human), consumption of blood with rum.

Obeah: Secret incantations (mumbling in 'unknown tongue'), rhythmic swaying, preparing charms (Obi) with various ingredients (blood, feathers, animal teeth/skulls, grave dirt, rum, eggshells), administering poisons (often subtly mixed in food/drink or applied to surfaces), 'turning him yeye' (hypnotism for influence), 'catching shadows' (in later Myalistic context).

Myalism: Public dances (Myal dance, later Revivalism, Pocomanism) often under cotton trees, fowl sacrifices, wild songs, ecstatic trance and possession, 'digging up Obeah' (exorcising evil charms), 'catching shadows' of the living to restore health, anointing with oils.

Concerning the origin of this worship of the serpent at Whydah he states: "The principal divinity of the country is the serpent, although it is not known just when they began to acknowledge him, to render him a cult. They only know as absolutely certain that this pretended divinity came from the Kingdom of Ardra. These Whydahs having undertaken to give battle to the Ardras, a large serpent left the enemy's army and came to deliver himself to that of Whydah. But he appeared so gentle, that instead of biting like the other animals of his species, he caressed and embraced everybody. The chief sacrificer made bold to take hold of him and raise him up on high to bring him in view of the entire army, which, astonished at the prodigy, prostrated themselves before this compliant animal, and rushed on their enemies with such courage that they completely routed them. They did not fail to attribute their victory to this serpent. They respectfully carried him along, built him a house, brought him sustenance, and in a short time this new god eclipsed all the others, even the fetishes which were the first and oldest gods of the country."

According to the Negro Aradas,[10] who are the real devotees of Voodoo in the Colony, and who keep up its principles; and rules, Voodoo signifies an all powerful and supernatural being on whom depends whatever goes on in the world. But this being is the nonpoisonous serpent, or a kind of adder, and it is under its auspices that all those assemble who profess the same doctrine. 'Knowledge of the past, realization of the present, foreknowledge of the future, all pertain to this adder, which, however, agrees to communicate its power, and make known its wishes, only through the medium of a high priest whom its devotees select, and even more so through that of the Negress, whom the love of the other has raised to the rank of high priestess.

The term Obeah, Obiah, or Obia (for it is variously written), we conceive to be the adjective, and the Obe or Obi the noun substantive; and that by the words Obiah−men and women, are meant those who practice Obi. The origin of the term we should consider of no importance in our answer to the questions proposed, if, in search of it, we were not led to disquisitions that are highly gratifying to curiosity. Myalism, then, was the old tribal religion of the Ashanti which we have studied in detail in the preceding chapter, with some modifications due to conditions and circumstances. It drew its name from the Myal dance that featured it, particularly in the veneration of the minor deities who were subordinate to Accompong, and in the commemoration or intercession of ancestors.

Voodoo itself as described by Moreau de Saint−Méry bears a close resemblance to its prototype of Whydah, making due allowance for local conditions, and it clearly satisfies all our requisites to be classed as worship in the strict sense of the word, as distinct from a mere Cult.

critical_analysis.relevance: This book offers a foundational historical and anthropological perspective on Voodoo and Obeah, distinguishing them from each other and from broader 'witchcraft' categories. It is highly relevant for esoteric and occult studies as it provides an early, detailed, and critical analysis of these West Indian traditions, combating prevalent sensationalism. Its emphasis on African origins and syncretic evolution offers crucial context for understanding the development of Afro-Caribbean magical-religious systems. For practitioners, it provides a unique historical lens into the philosophical underpinnings and evolution of these traditions, highlighting the distinction between religious veneration and harmful sorcery.
critical_analysis.target_audience: Academic researchers in comparative religion, anthropology, and African diaspora studies. Scholars and practitioners of Western Esotericism, Occultism, and Afro-Caribbean magical traditions (e.g., Vodou, Obeah, Santería, Palo Mayombe) seeking to understand the historical roots, philosophical distinctions, and practical evolution of these systems beyond popular misconceptions. Historians interested in the socio-religious dynamics of slavery and post-emancipation societies in the West Indies.
